query: In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, what gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish?
relevant_summary: Several gear modifications are available for prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries to reduce unwanted fish catch. Size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets have been extensively tested, with 30 studies showing that seven of seven replicated studies found these grids reduced unwanted fish catches by allowing escape of unwanted sharks and other fish species (Action 2721). Size-sorting mesh funnels (sieve nets) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets reduced catches of unwanted fish compared to standard trawls in three replicated studies in the North Sea (Action 2722). Large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes and radial escape sections fitted to trawl nets reduced overall catches of unwanted fish, immature red snapper and total unwanted catch in six of seven replicated studies (Action 2723). Combinations of size-sorting escape grids and large supported escape openings reduced catches of unwanted fish and sharks and rays in three of four studies (Action 2726). Modified W-trawl net designs used in shrimp/prawn fisheries caught less non-commercial unwanted catch of crustaceans compared to traditional Florida Flyer trawl nets (Action 2139). Topless (coverless) trawls reduced unwanted catches in two of four studies, with reductions in Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species (Action 2712). Bottom trawls with parts of the gear raised off the seabed caught fewer unwanted sharks, other elasmobranchs and fish compared to conventional trawls (Action 2708). Mesh escape panels/windows with square mesh instead of diamond mesh codends reduced numbers of discarded finfish (Action 2724), and modifications to the configuration of mesh escape panels reduced unwanted catches in three of five studies (Action 2717). Different designs or configurations of size-sorting escape grid systems showed variable effectiveness, with six of sixteen studies finding reductions in unwanted catches of fish species (Action 2728).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty studies examined the effects of fitting size-sorting escape grids to prawn/shrimp trawl nets on marine fish populations. Five studies were in the North Sea (Scotland/Norway, Belgium/Netherlands, UK, Scotland), four were in the Coral Sea (Australia) and two were in each of the Gulf of Carpentaria (Australia), the Indian Ocean (Australia, Mozambique), the North Atlantic Ocean (Portugal, USA), the Pacific Ocean (Chile, USA), the Skagerrak and Kattegat (northern Europe) and the South Atlantic Ocean (Brazil). One study was in each of the Tasman Sea (Australia), the Greenland Sea (Svalbard), the Bay of Biscay (France), the Gulf of Maine (USA), the Gulf of Thailand (Vietnam), the Tyrrhenian Sea (Italy), the Gulf of St Vincent (Australia), the Persian Gulf (Iran) and the Northeast Atlantic Ocean (Norway).

POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (30 STUDIES)

Reduction of unwanted catch (30 studies): Seven of seven replicated studies (including one controlled) in the northeast Atlantic Ocean, North Sea, North Atlantic Ocean, Greenland Sea, Gulf of Thailand, Tyrrhenian Sea and the Skagerrak and Kattegat found that fitting rigid or flexible size-sorting escape grids, of various types and configurations, to prawn/shrimp trawl nets reduced unwanted fish catches (non-commercial species and discarded commercial species/sizes) by allowing the escape of unwanted sharks and the other fish species monitored. Two of two before-and-after studies in the Gulf of Maine and Pacific Ocean found that after the introduction of size-sorting escape grids to trawl nets in fisheries for shrimp, the capture of non-target and unwanted fish was reduced compared to before grids were used. Eleven of 20 replicated studies (including one controlled and 19 paired and controlled) in the Tasman Sea, Coral Sea, Gulf of Carpentaria, North Sea, Indian Ocean, Bay of Biscay, Skagerrak and Kattegat, Pacific Ocean, South Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of St Vincent and Persian Gulf found that prawn/shrimp trawls with size-sorting escape grids, of various types and configurations, had lower catches of all or all but one undersized or otherwise unwanted fish and shark/ray species monitored, and unwanted total catch (fish and invertebrates), compared to trawl nets without escape grids. Two found that escape grids reduced non-target catches of most sizes of whiting and plaice and larger sizes of total fish, but increased the retention of small cod and haddock. Three studies found a variable effect of fitting escape grids to shrimp/prawn trawl nets on unwanted fish catch compared to nets with no grids, and the effect varied with year, site and grid type. Three found that grids had no effect on the reduction of unwanted fish and catches were similar for all or most of the unwanted non-commercial and commercial fish species/groups and for the total unwanted catch (fish and invertebrates). The other study found that fewer unwanted fish of 10 of 11 species/groups were retained in a shrimp/prawn trawl net with an escape grid used in combination with a diamond mesh codend with the mesh orientation turned by 90°, compared to a conventional diamond mesh net with no grid. One replicated, randomized study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that the reduction in catch of unwanted sharks depended on the type of escape grid and shrimp/prawn trawl net used."

POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)

Reduction of unwanted catch (17 studies): Six of 16 replicated studies (eight paired and controlled, three controlled, one randomized and controlled, and one paired) in the Atlantic Ocean, a laboratory, Arafura Sea, Barents Sea, Kattegat and Skagerrak, Greenland Sea, North Sea, Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean, and one controlled study in the Barents Sea found that using a different design or configuration of size-sorting escape grid/system in trawl nets reduced the unwanted (undersized, non-target, discarded) catches of all or most of the fish species assessed, compared to standard or other grid designs/configurations. Four studies found that the effect of using different escape grids on the reduction of unwanted catch varied with fish species, light conditions, and the type of trawl net used. The other six found that, overall, using a different escape grid did not reduce unwanted fish catch.

query: What are the most effective modifications for static fishing gear, like gillnets and traps, to reduce unwanted fish catch?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from multiple studies, several modifications to static fishing gear have proven effective at reducing unwanted catch. For gillnets, modifications including reduced height, increased tension, twine diameter, and mesh size and orientation successfully reduced unwanted catch of cod in one of two net designs, discarded fish of commercial and non-commercial species, and discards of non-commercial species compared to conventional configurations, though one study found gillnet modifications did not typically reduce unwanted shark catches (Action 2701). For fishing traps and pots, the most effective modifications include: increasing mesh size, which reduced unwanted catches of fish overall and improved size-selectivity for multiple species including Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most fish species, and specifically reduced unwanted undersized mud crabs (Actions 2702, 2148); fitting escape devices such as soft, semi-rigid, or rigid grids or frames, which reduced unwanted undersized mud crabs (Actions 2146, 2149); using square mesh escape windows or larger mesh sizes, which improved size-selectivity of Atlantic cod, black sea bass and most fish species (Action 2702); and using different trap types with various escape devices that reduced unwanted catches of multiple fish species including brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse, leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel, winter flounder, and sharks/rays (Action 2702). The combination of fitting escape frames with larger mesh sizes appeared particularly effective at reducing unwanted undersized catches (Action 2149). However, different bait species in traps did not change the amount of unwanted invertebrates caught (Action 2145).

query: What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries?
relevant_summary:
Commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries can use several gear modifications to reduce unwanted fish catch. Size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets represent one of the most widely studied modifications, with thirty studies showing that these devices reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of non-commercial species and discarded commercial species/sizes (Action 2721). Different designs and configurations of these escape grids have been tested in twenty-three studies, with six of sixteen studies finding reduced unwanted catches of fish species (Action 2728).

Size-sorting mesh funnels (sieve nets) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets reduce catches of unwanted non-commercial or discarded fish compared to standard trawls (Action 2722). Combining escape grids with large, supported escape openings reduces catches of unwanted fish and sharks and rays, with three of four studies showing effectiveness (Action 2726).

Mesh escape panels/windows can be modified in configuration including position, size and mesh size, with three of five studies showing reduced unwanted catches of certain fish species like whiting, haddock and boarfish (Action 2717). When mesh escape panels/windows are combined with size-sorting grids, four of five studies found reduced unwanted catch of fish, sharks and stingrays compared to standard unmodified trawl nets (Action 2727).

Other modifications include raising parts of bottom trawl gear off the seabed, which reduces catches of unwanted sharks, other elasmobranchs and fish species (Action 2708). Topless or coverless trawls reduce unwanted catches in two of four studies, particularly for Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species (Action 2712). Moving stimulator devices fitted to trawl nets can increase fish escape response, though effectiveness varies by species and requires combination with other devices in some cases (Action 2729).

Modified designs of W-trawl nets specifically for shrimp/prawn fisheries catch less non-commercial unwanted catch of crustaceans compared to traditional Florida Flyer trawl nets (Action 2139).

One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger but not smaller haddock and larger Atlantic cod only in one of two cases, compared to standard trawl types. The other study found that discarded catches of one of four commercial fish species were reduced in topless trawls."

{
  "action_id": "2721",
  "action_title": "Fit a size-sorting escape grid (rigid or flexible) to a prawn/shrimp trawl net",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty studies examined the effects of fitting size-sorting escape grids to prawn/shrimp trawl nets on marine fish populations. Five studies were in the North Sea (Scotland/Norway, Belgium/Netherlands, UK, Scotland), four were in the Coral Sea (Australia) and two were in each of the Gulf of Carpentaria (Australia), the Indian Ocean (Australia, Mozambique), the North Atlantic Ocean (Portugal, USA), the Pacific Ocean (Chile, USA), the Skagerrak and Kattegat (northern Europe) and the South Atlantic Ocean (Brazil). One study was in each of the Tasman Sea (Australia), the Greenland Sea (Svalbard), the Bay of Biscay (France), the Gulf of Maine (USA), the Gulf of Thailand (Vietnam), the Tyrrhenian Sea (Italy), the Gulf of St Vincent (Australia), the Persian Gulf (Iran) and the Northeast Atlantic Ocean (Norway).

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (30 STUDIES)

Reduction of unwanted catch (30 studies): Seven of seven replicated studies (including one controlled) in the northeast Atlantic Ocean, North Sea, North Atlantic Ocean, Greenland Sea, Gulf of Thailand, Tyrrhenian Sea and the Skagerrak and Kattegat found that fitting rigid or flexible size-sorting escape grids, of various types and configurations, to prawn/shrimp trawl nets reduced unwanted fish catches (non-commercial species and discarded commercial species/sizes) by allowing the escape of unwanted sharks and the other fish species monitored. Two of two before-and-after studies in the Gulf of Maine and Pacific Ocean found that after the introduction of size-sorting escape grids to trawl nets in fisheries for shrimp, the capture of non-target and unwanted fish was reduced compared to before grids were used. Eleven of 20 replicated studies (including one controlled and 19 paired and controlled) in the Tasman Sea, Coral Sea, Gulf of Carpentaria, North Sea, Indian Ocean, Bay of Biscay, Skagerrak and Kattegat, Pacific Ocean, South Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of St Vincent and Persian Gulf found that prawn/shrimp trawls with size-sorting escape grids, of various types and configurations, had lower catches of all or all but one undersized or otherwise unwanted fish and shark/ray species monitored, and unwanted total catch (fish and invertebrates), compared to trawl nets without escape grids. Two found that escape grids reduced non-target catches of most sizes of whiting and plaice and larger sizes of total fish, but increased the retention of small cod and haddock. Three studies found a variable effect of fitting escape grids to shrimp/prawn trawl nets on unwanted fish catch compared to nets with no grids, and the effect varied with year, site and grid type. Three found that grids had no effect on the reduction of unwanted fish and catches were similar for all or most of the unwanted non-commercial and commercial fish species/groups and for the total unwanted catch (fish and invertebrates). The other study found that fewer unwanted fish of 10 of 11 species/groups were retained in a shrimp/prawn trawl net with an escape grid used in combination with a diamond mesh codend with the mesh orientation turned by 90°, compared to a conventional diamond mesh net with no grid. One replicated, randomized study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that the reduction in catch of unwanted sharks depended on the type of escape grid and shrimp/prawn trawl net used."
}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-three studies examined the effects of using a different design or configuration of size-sorting escape grid/system in trawl fishing gear on marine fish populations. Ten studies were in the Atlantic Ocean (Canada, USA, Brazil, Spain, Norway). Five studies were in the Barents and/or Norwegian Sea (Norway). Two studies were in the Kattegat and Skagerrak (Denmark/Sweden). One study was in each of the Arafura Sea (Australia), the Greenland Sea (Norway), the North Sea (Norway), the North Pacific Ocean (USA) and the Indian Ocean (Australia). One study was in a laboratory (Japan). 

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (23 STUDIES)

Reduction of unwanted catch (17 studies): Six of 16 replicated studies (eight paired and controlled, three controlled, one randomized and controlled, and one paired) in the Atlantic Ocean, a laboratory, Arafura Sea, Barents Sea, Kattegat and Skagerrak, Greenland Sea, North Sea, Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean, and one controlled study in the Barents Sea found that using a different design or configuration of size-sorting escape grid/system in trawl nets reduced the unwanted (undersized, non-target, discarded) catches of all or most of the fish species assessed, compared to standard or other grid designs/configurations. Four studies found that the effect of using different escape grids on the reduction of unwanted catch varied with fish species, light conditions, and the type of trawl net used. The other six found that, overall, using a different escape grid did not reduce unwanted fish catch.
Improve size-selectivity of fishing gear (7 studies): Three of seven replicated studies (three controlled, one paired and controlled) in the Barents/Norwegian Sea, the Atlantic Ocean and the Greenland Sea found that different types or configurations of size-sorting escape grid systems in trawl nets resulted in better size-selectivity for unwanted redfish and Greenland halibut and of commercial target hake compared to other designs or configurations. Three studies found that the effect of using a different design or configuration of size-sorting escape grid/system on improving the size-selectivity of trawls varied between fish species compared to standard or other escape grid designs. The other study found that a new design of grid system did not improve the size-selectivity of unwanted redfish compared to an existing system."

The other studies found that catches of unwanted cod or other fish were not reduced.
Improved size-selectivity of fishing gear (4 studies): Two of four replicated, controlled studies in the North Sea and Baltic Sea found that modifying the position and/or size of a mesh escape panel in a trawl net improved size-selectivity of haddock and whiting. The other two studies found that size-selectivity was similar for cod compared to standard trawls."

The other study found that the escape of non-target fish from the combined use of a square mesh panel and grid depended on the position of the panel in the net.
Improved size-selectivity of fishing gear (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in the English Channel found that size-selectivity of whiting was increased in bottom trawl nets fitted with square mesh escape panels or cylinders in combination with one or two size-sorting grids of different types, compared to standard nets."

{"summary": "Commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries can use several gear modifications to reduce unwanted fish catch. Size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets represent one of the most widely studied modifications, with thirty studies showing that these devices reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of non-commercial species and discarded commercial species/sizes (Action 2721). Different designs and configurations of these escape grids have been tested in twenty-three studies, with six of sixteen studies finding reduced unwanted catches of fish species (Action 2728).

Size-sorting mesh funnels (sieve nets) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets reduce catches of unwanted non-commercial or discarded fish compared to standard trawls (Action 2722). Combining escape grids with large, supported escape openings reduces catches of unwanted fish and sharks and rays, with three of four studies showing effectiveness (Action 2726).

Mesh escape panels/windows can be modified in configuration including position, size and mesh size, with three of five studies showing reduced unwanted catches of certain fish species like whiting, haddock and boarfish (Action 2717). When mesh escape panels/windows are combined with size-sorting grids, four of five studies found reduced unwanted catch of fish, sharks and stingrays compared to standard unmodified trawl nets (Action 2727).

Other modifications include raising parts of bottom trawl gear off the seabed, which reduces catches of unwanted sharks, other elasmobranchs and fish species (Action 2708). Topless or coverless trawls reduce unwanted catches in two of four studies, particularly for Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species (Action 2712). Moving stimulator devices fitted to trawl nets can increase fish escape response, though effectiveness varies by species and requires combination with other devices in some cases (Action 2729).

Modified designs of W-trawl nets specifically for shrimp/prawn fisheries catch less non-commercial unwanted catch of crustaceans compared to traditional Florida Flyer trawl nets (Action 2139).", "action_ids": ["2139","2708","2712","2717","2721","2722","2726","2727","2728","2729"], "query": "What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries?"}

query: What is the evidence for gear modifications improving the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear?
relevant_summary: Multiple controlled studies provide evidence that various gear modifications can improve the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear. Five replicated, controlled studies in the North Sea and Mediterranean Sea found that modifications to trawl gear, including changes to the length of the extension piece, the codend strengthening bag, the method of weaving, the number of codend layers and overall design improved the size-selectivity for unwanted (non-target/discarded) fish species or sizes, and annular seabream in one of two cases, compared to unmodified standard trawl gear or other design configurations (Action 2704). Four of five replicated studies in the North Sea, Baltic Sea and Adriatic Sea found that using different twine types (twine thickness and construction material) improved the size-selectivity of bottom fish, haddock, Atlantic cod, plaice and flounder, compared to thinner or other twine materials (Action 2710). Three of seven replicated studies in the Barents/Norwegian Sea, the Atlantic Ocean and the Greenland Sea found that different types or configurations of size-sorting escape grid systems in trawl nets resulted in better size-selectivity for unwanted redfish and Greenland halibut and of commercial target hake compared to other designs or configurations (Action 2728). Four of five replicated, controlled studies in the Baltic Sea, Aegean Sea, and North Sea found that turning the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° resulted in better size selection of cod, red mullet and common pandora, and round-bodied fish species, but not of plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species, compared to standard orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends (Action 2715). However, some modifications showed limited effects, as one replicated study in the North Sea found that reducing the size of the main body of a trawl net did not improve the size-selection of cod and haddock (Action 2705). Additionally, three replicated studies found that the effect of using a different design or configuration of size-sorting escape grid/system on improving the size-selectivity of trawls varied between fish species compared to standard or other escape grid designs (Action 2728).
